title: The One Where Mr. Heckles Dies

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Hey.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: So how was Joan?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I broke up with her.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: They were huge. When she sneezed, bats flew out of them.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Come on, they were not that huge.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I'm tellin' you, she leaned back, I could see her brain.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: How many perfectly fine women are you gonna reject over the most superficial insignificant things?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hold it hold it. I gotta side with Chandler on this one. When I first moved to the city, I went out a couple of times with this girl, really hot, great kisser, but she had the biggest Adam's apple. It made me nuts.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You or me?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I got it. Uh, Joey, women don't have Adam's apples.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: You guys are messin' with me, right?

dialogue.speaker: ALL
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: That was a good one. For a second there, I was like, "whoa."

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: You name one woman that you broke up with for a real reason.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Maureen Rosilla.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Not hating Yanni is not a real reason.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Hello, Mr. Heckles.

dialogue.speaker: MR. HECKLES
dialogue.text: You're doing it again.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: We're not doing anything.

dialogue.speaker: MR. HECKLES
dialogue.text: You're stomping. It's disturbing my birds.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: You don't have birds.

dialogue.speaker: MR. HECKLES
dialogue.text: I could have birds.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Ok, Mr. Heckles, we'll try to keep it down.

dialogue.speaker: MR. HECKLES
dialogue.text: Thank you. I'm going to rejoin my dinner party.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: All right, bye-bye.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Ok, Janice. Janice. You gotta give me Janice. That wasn't about being picky.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: We'll give you Janice.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I miss Janice though. "Hello, Chandler Bing."

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: "Oh, my, god."

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: "Oh, Chandler, now, now, that's it. There, faster!"

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Stop with the broom, we're not making noise.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: We won. We won!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Mr. Heckles.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: How did this happen?

dialogue.speaker: MR. TREEGER
dialogue.text: He musta been sweepin'. They found a broom in his hand.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: That's terrible.

dialogue.speaker: MR. TREEGER
dialogue.text: I know. I was sweepin' ye

dialogue.speaker: MR. TREEGER
dialogue.text: You never know.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ok, it's very faint, but I can still sense him in the building. Go into the light, Mr. Heckles!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Ok, Phoebe.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, but sometimes they need help. That's fine. Go ahead and scoff. You know, there're a lot of things that I don't believe in, but that doesn't mean they're not true.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Such as?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Like crop circles, or the Bermuda triangle, or evolution?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. What, you don't, uh, you don't believe in evolution?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Nah. Not really.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: You don't believe in evolution?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I don't know, it's just, you know...monkeys, Darwin, you know, it's a, it's a nice story, I just think it's a little too easy.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Too easy? Too...The process of every living thing on this planet evolving over millions of years from single-celled organisms, too easy?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Yeah, I just don't buy it.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Uh, excuse me. Evolution is not for you to buy, Phoebe. Evolution is scientific fact, like, like, like the air we breathe, like gravity.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ok, don't get me started on gravity.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: You uh, you don't believe in gravity?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Well, it's not so much that you know, like I don't believe in it, you know, it's just...I don't know, lately I get the feeling that I'm not so much being pulled down as I am being pushed.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Uh-Oh. It's Isaac Newton, and he's pissed.

dialogue.speaker: MR. TREEGER
dialogue.text: There she is. And over there, that's the other one. This is Mr. Buddy Boyle, Mr. Heckles' attorney. He'd like to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: What can we do for you?

dialogue.speaker: MR. BOYLE
dialogue.text: All right, kids. Here's the deal. According to my client's will, he wants to leave all his earthly possessions to "the noisy girls in the apartment above mine".

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Well, what about his family?

dialogue.speaker: MR. BOYLE
dialogue.text: He didn't have any.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Ok, so let's talk money.

dialogue.speaker: MR. BOYLE
dialogue.text: All right, there was none. Let's talk signing. You be noisy girl number one, you be noisy girl number two.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: I can't believe that this whole time we thought he hated us. I mean, isn't it amazing how much you can touch someone's life, without even knowing it?...Would you look at this dump? He hated us. This is his final revenge!

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Have you ever seen so much crap?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Actually, I think this apartment sullies the good name of crap

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Check this out. Can I have this?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: How can you not believe in evolution?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Just don't. Look at this funky shirt!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Pheebs, I have studied evolution my entire adult life. Ok, I can tell you, we have collected fossils from all over the world that actually show the evolution of different species, ok? You can literally see them evolving through time.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Really? You can actually see it?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: You bet. In the U.S., China, Africa, all over.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: See, I didn't know that.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well, there you go.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Huh. So now, the real question is, who put those fossils there, and why?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Hey, look at this. "My Big Book of Grievances."

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey, there's me! April 17th. Excessive noise. Italian guy comes homes with a date. Hey Chandler, look, you're in here too.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: April 18th, excessive noise. Italian guy's gay roommate comes home with the dry-cleaning. Well that's excellent.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Monica, Monica, look at this lamp. Is this tacky or what? We have to have this.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Rache, I think we have enough regular lamps.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What? Come on, it's not like I'm asking for this girly clock or anything, which, by the way, I also think is very cool.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: It doesn't go with any of my stuff.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well, what about my stuff?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: You don't have any stuff.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: You still think of it as your apartment, don't you?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yes you do. You think of it as your apartment, and I'm just somebody who rents a room.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Mmmmm.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Ok, while you "mmm" on it for awhile, I'm gonna go find a place for my new lamp.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Ok, Pheebs. See how I'm making these little toys move? Opposable thumbs. Without evolution, how do you explain opposable thumbs?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Maybe the overlords needed them to steer their spacecrafts.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Please tell me you're joking.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Look, can't we just say that you believe in something, and I don't.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: No, no, Pheebs, we can't, ok, because--

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: What is this obsessive need you have to make everyone agree with you? No, what's that all about? I think, I think maybe it's time you put Ross under the microscope.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Is there blood coming out of my ears?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Check it out, check it out. Heckles' high school yearbook.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Wow, he looks so normal.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: He's even kind of cute.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: "Heckles, you crack me up in science class. You're the funniest kid in school.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Funniest? Heckles?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: That's what it says.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Wow, Heckles was voted class clown, and so was I. He was right. Would you listen to that?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I'd call that excessive.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Whoa!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Heckles played clarinet in band, and I played clarinet. And he was in the scale modeler's club, and I was, well, there was no club, but I sure thought they were cool.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: So, you were both dorks. Big deal.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I just think it's weird, you know? Heckles and me, Heckles, and me, me and Heckles...Would you knock it off?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Have you been here all night?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Look at this. Pictures of all the women that Heckles went out with. Look what he wrote on them. Vivian, too tall. Madge, big gums. Too loud, too smart, makes noise when she eats. This is, this is me. This is what I do. I'm gonna end up alone, just like he did.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Chandler, Heckles was a nut case.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Our trains are on the same track, ok? Yeah, sure, I'm coming up 30 years behind him, but the stops are all the same. Bitter Town. Aloneville. Hermit Junction.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: All right, you know what we gotta do? We gotta get you outta here. Come on, I'll buy you breakfast, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: What if I never find someone? Or worse, what if I've found her, but I dumped her because she pronounced it "supposably"?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Chandler, come on, you're gonna find somebody.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: How do you know that? How?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: I don't know, I'm just tryin' to help you out.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You'll see, you guys are all gonna go off and get married, and I'm gonna end up alone. Will you promise me something? When you're married, will you invite me over for holidays?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know. I don't know what we're gonna be doin'. I mean, what if we're at her folks' place?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yeah, I understand.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: You can come over and watch the Super Bowl. Every year, all right?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You know what? I'm not gonna end up like this. I'll see you man.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Supposably. Supposably. Did they go to the zoo? Supposably.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (on phone) Hi, it's me.

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Oh, my, god.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Janice? You called Janice?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yes, Janice. Why is that so difficult for you to comprehend?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: You remember Janice, right?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yes. She was smart, she was pretty, and she honestly cared about me. Janice is my last chance to have somebody.

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Helloo!!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Oh, my, god!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Geez, look how fat she got.

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Hey, it's everybody.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Janice, you're--

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Is it--?

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Is it yours? Ha! You wish, Chandler Bing. You are looking at a married lady now.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Congratulations.

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Oh, sweetie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You couldn't have told me about this on the phone?

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: And what? Missed the expression on your face? Janice likes to have her fun.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Hey, Rache. You know what we haven't played in a while?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Hide the Lamp.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Monica, let it go.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Did you know I was allergic to shellfish?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well, then, you'll just have to eat the other lamps.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Uh-oh. It's Scary Scientist Man.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Ok, Phoebe, this is it. In this briefcase I carry actual scientific facts. A briefcase of facts, if you will. Some of these fossils are over 200 million years old.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ok, look, before you even start, I'm not denying evolution, ok, I'm just saying that it's one of the possibilities.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: It's the only possibility, Phoebe.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ok, Ross, could you just open your mind like this much, ok? Wasn't there a time when the brightest minds in the world believed that the world was flat? And, up until like what, 50 years ago, you all thought the atom was the smallest thing, until you split it open, and this like, whole mess of crap came out. Now, are you telling me that you are so unbelievably arrogant that you can't admit that there's a teeny tiny possibility that you could be wrong about this?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: There might be, a teeny, tiny, possibility.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I can't believe you caved.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: You just abandoned your whole belief system. I mean, before, I didn't agree with you, but at least I respected you. How, how, how are you going to go into work tomorrow? How, how are you going to face the other science guys? How, how are you going to face yourself? Oh! That was fun. So who's hungry?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I am. Let me just get my coat.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Ok, all right. It was an accident, I swear, all right. I was putting on my jacket, and the thing, and the lamp, and it broke.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Oh, please, Monica. You've always hated my lamp, and then, all of a sudden, it's just magically broken?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Phoebe, tell her!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ok, I didn't see it, because I was putting on my jacket, but I uh want to believe you.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Hey Chandler. Monica just broke my seashell lamp.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Neat. I'm gonna die alone.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Ok, you win.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Chandler, you're not gonna die alone.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Janice was my safety net, ok? And now I have to get a snake.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Uh huh. Why is that?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: If I'm gonna be an old, lonely man, I'm gonna need a thing, you know, a hook, like that guy on the subway who eats his own face. So I figure I'll be Crazy Man with a Snake, y=know. Crazy Snake Man. And I'll get more snakes, call them my babies, kids will walk past my place, they will run. "Run away from Crazy Snake Man," they'll shout!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: You have got to get over this. You're not gonna end up alone.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Of course I am. I reject anyone who's crazy enough to actually go out with me, and then I bitch about the fact that there aren't any great women out there.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Chandler, you have just described virtually every man that we have ever gone out with.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: You are not a freak. You're a guy.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: She's right. She's right. You are no different than the rest of them.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, wait a minute. Yes he is. You are totally different.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: In a bad way?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: No, honey, in a wonderful way. You know what you want now. Most guys don't even have a clue. You are ready to take risks, you are ready to be vulnerable, and intimate with someone.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah. You're not gonna end up alone.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Chandler, you called Janice! That's how much you wanted to be with someone!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: You made it!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: You're there!

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: You are ready to make a commitment!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Whoa! Don't know about that.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What you got there? Something else that's not yours that you can break?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: No. Um, I know you like this, and I want you to have it. I think it'll look good in our apartment.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: That's fine.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Hey. Well, you will all be pleased to know that I have a date tomorrow night. This woman, Alison, from work. She's great. She's pretty, she's smart. And uh, I've been holding off on asking her out in the past, because she has an unusually large head. But, I'm not gonna let that stuff hang me up anymore. Look at me. I'm growing.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey, uh, you can't recycle yearbooks, can you?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I'll take that.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: You want his yearbook?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah. Some people said some nice things about him. I think somebody should have it.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Oh, gosh, this is so weird. I mean, his whole life was in this apartment, and now it's gone. You know, I think it would be nice if we just took a few moments, for Mr. Heckles. I mean, he was kind of a pain, he was, but, he was a person. You're all going to hell.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: It's really not that big!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Takin' that with you, huh?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: You comin'?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yeah, jus' second. Good-bye Mr. Heckles. We'll try to keep it down.

dialogue.speaker: ALISON
dialogue.text: Oh, my major was totally useless. I mean, how often do you look in the classifieds and see "Philosopher wanted"?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Sure. (My god, that's a big head! It didn't look this big in the office. Maybe it's the lighting. My head must look like a golf ball at work. All right, don't get hung up on it, quick, quick, list

dialogue.speaker: FIVE THINGS YOU LIKE ABOUT HER
dialogue.text: Nice smile, good dresser...Big head, big head, big head!)

subjects: FIVE THINGS YOU LIKE ABOUT HER
